1. We must seek to make the new man entire and per- fect in all his members: for as the natural body appears deformed if deprived of an eye, a hand, or a foot, or any other of its members3 so it is with the spiritual man, if he lack any of his parts.

2. They have little or no sense of spiritual life, who do not perceive, or perceiving do not grieve for, or grieving for do not endeavour with all their might to amend and supply, this mutilation of the new man.

3. Scarcely will an individual be found who, as far as respects this new man, is not a monster either from defi- ciency or superabundance of limbs: I mean wanting in the members he ought to have, or supplied with those he should be without. But if we would attend to the Apostle, we shall understand, that from the fact of our having put off the old Adam, and put on the new man, we are bound to suffer any inconvenience which may occur in either respect. Thus much of the illative particle therefore.
